notes.text: In its standard use, literally means ‘in a literal sense, as opposed to a nonliteral or exaggerated sense’: I told him I never wanted to see him again, but I didn't expect him to take it literally. In recent years, an extended use of literally (and also literal) has become very common, where literally (or literal) is used deliberately in nonliteral contexts, for added effect: they bought the car and literally ran it into the ground. This use can lead to unintentional humorous effects (we were literally killing ourselves laughing) and is not acceptable in formal English

definitions: in a literal manner or sense; exactly

examples.text: the driver took it literally when asked to go straight across the traffic circle

definitions: used for emphasis or to express strong feeling while not being literally true

examples.text: I was literally blown away by the response I got

shortDefinitions: used for emphasis while not being literally true
